job_title: Customer Service Representative in Tigard, OR
pros: Work from home Incredible benefits All holidays paid off plus extra 5 floater paid days 2 weeks vacation paid starting off
cons: cant think of any cons

pros: Able to work remotely for a bit.
cons: The pay is not good for what the job is. Only people who are listened to are higher ups, they always keep the customers happier than the employees and will blame the employee(s) for any and every issue. Worst HR department, terrible people who are not educated and do not do their job. Unprofessional management, burn through customer service reps like crazy. You will only hear from them if you are being blamed for a mistake or you’re in trouble for something. You will not get any recognition for anything you do well and no support will be provided even when you ask. They did have a DE&I training and it was then promptly forgotten about and many people said they “didn’t get it”, if that’s something that’s important to you (and it should be) run from Road Scholar. Needless to say, the “culture” is nonexistent. Jim Moses has no idea what’s going on with the company and it shows, as it keeps going downhill fast.

pros: Working remote and avoiding long commutes
cons: Management is unclear in communicating with their employees. They give the illusion that your voice and feelings matter, but ultimately your voice will get lost in the "busy-ness" of call center work. If you're someone who needs more agency in your profession, do not work for this company. Not only will they tell you how to do each task, but in what order each little task needs to be done. They will tell you how to speak, how to feel, how to think. Not a lot of room for growth or for moving to other departments outside of the one that hires you. I believe this strongly limits the company as everyone tends to get stuck in the same role and no one understands how the other departments work. This caused frequent issues with the sales people who would tell customers things that were not true about booking flights. It can result in having people in positions they don't even like with no escape. The jog offers benefits, but I feel as if the benefits are mediocre considering how much stress, anxiety, and work the job actually is. My entire training class was hired during the absolute worst time to work in the travel industry. We were forced to stay late every day to answer calls, we answered call after call after call all day long. We dealt with customers who were irate at the company for not booking flights earlier for them or angry at the sales people for lying to them about flights. Some were just downright verbally and emotionally abusive.

pros: Great community to be a part of as a young person starting my career with plenty of opportunity to travel. Exceptional benefits
cons: Difficult to grow within the organization, low pay with few opportunities for advancement

pros: Remote opportunities Remote opportunities Remote opportunities Remote opportunities
cons: - The HR manager does not know how to properly provide feedback - Misleading/toxic work environment

pros: Work/life balance Close to home
cons: Management promotes thier favorite regardless if the qualified

review_title: Great place to start your career
pros: People are great and the atmosphere is easygoing
cons: Under market salaries for your work, great as an entry level job to get into a specific career

job_title: Sales/ Service Advisor  in Lowell, MA
pros: Very flexible of you make your numbers. Sent employees on trips
cons: Not flexible if you doing make your numbers

pros: Occasional free trips (for some people), nice customers
cons: Very disorganized and constantly changing protocol. Overlap between departments

review_title: Great Place to Work for Hard Workers
pros:
The people at Road Scholar are are great and there is a real sense of comradery with your peers. They make an effort to make the environment fun, but work still comes first. There are some travel perks with the job after a year, and the organization is dedicated to its mission. 

Road Scholar is a company with integrity towards its customers, and is know for "doing the right thing", even during the pandemic. Road Scholar offered cash back to participants whose programs were cancelled if requested. Most travel companies only offered vouchers for future travel.

You can work your way up to some management levels if willing to work in Boston, but breaking into the Senior management level is challenging, as many employees are long term and don't intend to leave.

For a not-for-profit salaries are good, but commercial travel likely pays more, but working in a mission driven environment feels better.
cons: Hard work is expected which can lead to long hours, but there is still a team spirit in terms of all working hard together. Management is inconsistent across departments, so expectations of work and behavior vary. Sometimes opinions and suggestions are not heard by a few in leadership. They made efforts for more management training to help with the inconsistency and created values to reinforce behavior results.

review_title: A good job that got ruined by the Global Pandemic
job_title: Customer Support Representative in Boston, MA
pros:
-Cool Company with travel perks
-Leadership cared
cons:
-Non-Profit made salaries tough
- Ruined by Pandemic

job_title: Inbound Sales Supervisor in Lowell, MA
pros: Excellent career pathing, great retirement plan and benefits, travel opportunities, amazing peers to work alongside, great company culture
cons: Communication can sometimes get muddy between departments

job_title: Director of Public Relations in Boston, MA
pros: Working for a nonprofit that does good things feels good, and RS cares about their employees and does what they can to provide good benefits, including travel opportunities.
cons: But, as with any job, there are frustrations and challenges within the organization. Company culture and communications being two of them, as well as financial limitations of being a nonprofit.

review_title: Solid job with room for growth
job_title: Blended Sales Customer Service in Portland, OR
pros: It was a healthy work environment with lots of room to grow within the company.
cons: My position was in the call center so when covid happened things got rough with our otherwise very nice clients.

pros: They listen to their employees
cons: The pay is not very wonderful

review_title: Solid call center job with room to grow
job_title: Blended Sales Customer Service in Portland, OR
pros: The leadership was very encouraging and enthusiastic about workplace culture and promoting from within.
cons: My position was essentially a call center job and due to the pandemic had to deal with a lot of unhappy customers.

job_title: Customer Service Associate in Boston, MA
pros: Great co workers and supervisors
cons: calls were monitored to often

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Portland, OR
pros: If you need something for three months, that's fine, but only as a last resort.
cons: Micromanagement. Sleazy practices for a nonprofit. Dead-end.

job_title: Travel Service Agent in Lowell, MA
pros: It was a great place to work in many ways. Friendly atmosphere, good benefits, travel opportunities, etc
cons: A lot of the perks disappeared after COVID. Office atmosphere, while friendly in appearance, can be very caddy and immature behind the scenes. It was not uncommon for rumors and gossip to spread around. Management tended to be very secretive and deceptive regarding changes

pros: Tenure was brief so not a ton of feedback. Everyone seemed open and welcoming.
cons: Tenure was brief due to Covid. No cons to report.

pros: Road Scholar is a place that cares about its employees and participants
cons: It is what you make it

pros: Occasional Free Trips and guide positions
cons: Very disorganized and work being pushed around to other departments. The pay is very low and the higher-ups avoid taking any responsibility for mistakes

pros: Great people and wonderful mission
cons: Travel org struggles during times when it’s not good to travel

pros: everyone is friendly and kindness
cons: too many things to work on

pros: We believe in the mission
cons: None that I can think of

pros: Wonderful people who are committed to educational travel for boomers and seniors.
cons: While leadership is thoughtful and considerate, sometimes speed is called for when making decisions and taking action.

pros: I'm only typing something here because it is required. Maybe one upside was how close the office was. That's it. I also wish I could rate them less than one star overall.
cons: If you would like to be respected in your work place, I would highly recommend you look elsewhere. The interview process was completely different than the overall work experience. Management is so ridiculously strict. Every few weeks you have a sit down with your supervisor to review how much time you went into "unavailable" on your phone. Excuse us for being humans and taking longer than 2 minutes to use the bathroom!!! On their job postings they say they encourage creativity and innovation. Absolutely not. If you question upper management they will just shoot you down and make you feel like you crossed the line for questioning anything. The turnover rate is incredibly high. They're always hiring on Craigslist and their company site because they are so desperate. Late work hours. Latest shift is 7pm, however there is a very likely possibility you get a phone call at 6:56 (when phones shut off) and you MUST stay on the call until the participant is ready. So sometimes you're looking at 7:30-7:45..... No time to really get to know the employees. Just a very sad work environment that made me hate the travel industry for quite awhile.

pros: Great management, people and environment
cons: Pay rate for new hires

review_title: A great organization to work for!
pros: Travel Opportunities, Fun work environment, great organization leadership
cons: I don't have any cons

review_title: Not a bad start, but not forever
pros:
This position allows a person to learn every facet of the company while growing professional skills. The benefits were pretty good, the parties were fun and most employees are really friendly. You get a chance to travel on a local program after your first year to gain first hand experience on what the company is "selling." 
The on site gym was perfect for the size of the company, it wasn't huge but it was adequate and allowed you to do what you need.
Location is amazing, probably one of the best areas I have worked in. Close to all of the subway lines, its in Financial District/Downtwon Xing/China town so your food/shopping choices are abundant.
Mr. Moses is an excellent CEO and is a great person to chat with, very friendly and down to earth.
cons: Difficult to move laterally. Some positions are treated as mere assistants even though these assistants are the backstage of the whole company. Some of the upper management were unable to help when needed, but overall everyone was still friendly. There seemed to be lack of interest in some departments. If you are a peon with good ideas, don't even bother...your ideas are unwelcome.

pros:
As a whole, Road Scholar is arguably one of the best employers I've ever had.  The Marketing team is a well-run, tight-knit group.  We support and applaud each other's ideas and accomplishments.  We even have a bell that we ring to mark when catalogs and brochure go to print, or when we release major updates to the web or other digital campaigns.  We all work really, really hard. Not every day is rose-colored but we do what we can to make it work.  

Key takeaways: Open-door policy, room for growth and advancement (even to other departments, if that's what you're interested in), tuition reimbursement, newly renovated gym in basement, free coffee (you will need it!), occasional bagel party, Culture Club, Holiday Parties, Tuition Reimbursement, Health Insurance is pretty good (United Healthcare / Harvard Pilgrim), INCREDIBLE retirement savings and employer contributions, travel benefits (for yourself and friends and family), and a lot more.
cons: The work load is tough.  We have a lot of assignments and deadlines, so management of your time (and working with the team to prioritize the lists) is key.  Communication between departments is lacking, which results in a lot of last-minute 911s that (most of the time) don't end up going anywhere.  The pay is lower for the same work than other companies.  Other departments struggle with tougher managers and blame-games instead of taking responsibility to help improve the overall process.

pros: Nice location in Boston and Lowell. Nothing else though.
cons: Road scholar is a non profit that runs like a for profit. Since they have brought in officials from a for profit things are not the same. People are on the edge of their seats wondering if this will be the day they are fired. They are constantly focusing on ridiculous stats. If you dont make the stats by even 2 percent you are on warning. Now they put many people on warning for not having enough referrals, even though everyone is asking. They also did it right in time for everyone's annual review so they don't have to give raises. They focus on money more than the mission now. Currently they take you into room for monitoring, so you can see any mistakes you make. They use intimidation tactics so you make sure you do everything perfectly. But even if everything is perfect they still make sure to find a flaw in something you do. The employees are miserable and morale is very low. They even reprimand you for using the bathroom. They don't treat us with the respect we deserve and it really is just an awful place to work now.

pros: independent work, 401k match program, benefits
cons: Roles tend to be overworked

pros: In my role at Road Scholar I interview many candidates for jobs, and, as such, I hear a lot of horror stories about what happens at other companies. That doesn't happen here. Everyone works very hard. Management makes a concerted effort to listen to employees. There is a balance of work, life and culture. If you put in your time here, show initiative, and try not to rush your way to the top, you will be very happy and successful here. You will not go from Associate to Vice President in a year here. You will work hard, you will put in your time, you will make incremental advances, and all along the way you will learn from people who have been at this for a long time but still have an open mind for change
cons: Growth and advancement takes time. Titles are real and not inflated which might be off-putting to new hires. Pay is a little lower than average, but you will still be able to live comfortably. Road Scholar can be conservative when it comes to taking risks and trying new things. Every idea gets hyper-analyzed to the nth degree. Though this might be why the organization continues to be as successful as it is after 43 years.

pros:
*Beautiful location in Boston and Lowell

*Close to MBTA 

*Boston supervisors seem to be a lot better than Lowell

*HR is wonderful
cons:
*training takes 6 weeks and at the end of it you can use the computer system. But it doesn't prepare you for anything you will be dealing with from day to day.

* In the interview they will tell you that they are one of the most easy call centers with more emphasis on building connections with participants. Build a connection means being friendly, but not over friendly, make a conversation but not TOO much conversation. Make people refer their friends, and if they don't have anyone MAKE sure you somehow get one anyway.

*Numbers, numbers, numbers. They will drill into you to get referrals and donations on every single call. Regardless of if the person has already called 3 times in a day, or just recently gave money. And with referrals you literally are scolded like a child if you don't get what they deem as the right amount.

review_title: Great organization but gross office politics (this can be changed)
pros:
- Extremely relaxed environment, open dress code, work from home benefits (pre-covid)
- Great benefits! And great work/life balance (set clear boundaries about this)
- Good enough technology
- THEY ACTUALLY TRUST YOU TO DO WORK BEING NEW - this is an issue I see at other places where they are reluctant to give you work because you're new to the workforce and maybe the don't trust you. Road Scholar does trust you and they will show it by giving you increasingly more responsibility. (At least my team was like this)
- I had the 2 best Managers a girl could ever dream of. Obviously this varies from team to team but I wanted to throw that out there.
cons:
- Pay is on the lower end of non-profit salaries
- Office politics!!! I was pretty blind to it my first 6 months of working there because I was so focused on learning my job, however there is lowkey drama that circulates the work place and people don't always speak their mind due to office politics. 
- Very hard to advance or get a raise
- They say its easy to transfer departments but I'm not entirely sure that is true
- Could be very clique-y at times.

review_title: Not Worth It!  Better to look elsewhere where you have value.
job_title: Call Center Representative in Lowell, MA
pros: Fair equipment and tools for a "Non-Profit" employer.  Moderate salaries, plenty of hours to work. Some minor perks.
cons: Major change in company focus here: Once was a unique niche offering a great product and excellent customer service.  Changed with their name change into giving less and less for higher cost (more so than competition even)  poor quality and push that sale at any cost. Nepotism rules the day.  Want someone to tell you EXACTLY how they want you to do something - ad nauseum - you've found it.  Constant badgering and micromanaging.  Health benefits are bottom of the barrel minimum coverage.  DON'T look to advance unless you've got an "in" with management. In fact, if you can get work elsewhere, don't waste your time here!

pros: Before today I never knew that my job was so essential. Apparently we save lives. Getting elderly people on a bus to tour the countryside, is right up there with firefighters, police and doctors. Come to Road Scholar and save lives through booking trips!
cons: They claim that we are essential personnel ( haha).  Boston is flooded and they don't care. They apparently want us to build a boat to get to work. According  to their policies they determine if it's really a state of emergency and don't listen to the Governor. They make up their own rules. Several people left and almost got into severe accidents during storms because they forced to come in or they would get fired. They seem not to care if someone  gets hurt or dies as long as they make a buck.  For a "nonprofit" company they really make it clear that their top priority is making money at any cost.

job_title: Registration Partcipant Services Advisor in Lowell, MA
pros:
close to home
surf the internet
read and sell travel tours
I went to couple one day tours in boston and salem, ma
ok company parties, benefits are ok
cons:
No internal growth
no big raises
quarterly incentives are to hard to obtain
talking on the phone with older adults who are rude, speak down to you. Some customers are hostile, grumpy, will try to get you in trouble if try to explain they do not like.
negative and subjective monthly, quarterly, yearly reviews that have be signed, but Superviors do not explain how scores are calculated.
non-profit
You take hundreds of call a day and answers questions, sell and get enrollments into tours.
Calls are recorded by managment. If don't mention special offers, get donations, new adds to catalogs mailing list, get alot of enrollments, managment does not think you are working hard. 
some co-workers have been rude to me and will snitch on you.
Getting donations and new adds to mailing list is out your control unless customer is generous.

job_title: Call Center Advisor in Boston, MA
pros: Great, wonderful co-workers, if you ever have the chance to talk. The office is in a nice location, close to the highway and downtown. Benefits are decent like incentive programs (extremely hard to get though).
cons: There is little room for growth in the company and they fail to recognize hard working employees, that are overworked. Upper management has a very unrealistic expectations. If you're off by 1-2% you are penalized. Only a very few people make the stats. There is only a five second break between calls, which is not enough time to do anything. You are expected to work like a machine. They assume if you aren't making the exact stats they expect that you are not working hard enough. In fact, the office had posters up saying "Do your job!".

review_title: Decent not-for-profit company, not so decent pay.
pros:
-Positive company mission
-Growing company
-Good people
-Some travel bonuses
-9-5 or 9-6 work schedule, no need to work on weekends (with only one or two weekends required annually)
-Outstanding retirement plan
cons:
-Payscale isn't congruous with today's needs (especially for those in Boston area)
-Some departments are poorly-trained and misadvise customers
-Over 5,500 individual tours really complicated the workload and product knowledge
-Benefits could really use some tweaking

review_title: Great Place, good wage, respectful managment
job_title: Inbound Sales and Service Advisor in Lowell, MA
pros:
Talking to (mostly) friendly elderly people who are excited to go traveling 
Weekly meetings keeping you up to date on whats going on in the company (helps you understand the inner workings, makes the culture of the workplace much better)
Good pay, I got $15ph with no previous experience in a call center
Great training, really preps you for the job before putting you out on the floor, The head trainer is excellent as well btw 
Time off is reasonable 2  weeks per year and management will really go the extra the mile if you need a day off 
option to do different work schedules (when available) I ended up doing 4 day weeks 10 hour shifts 
Mon-Fri 
Cant speak for all line managers, but mine was excellent. didn't micromanage but was always available if I needed some advice or training
cons:
sitting all day
(maybe con) I didnt get the health insurance myself but one person said it was lackluster but I do believe theyre working on improving it

review_title: A+ culture, some growing pains to work on. Still my favorite workplace and job (so far)
pros: Great community, most folks are committed to the mission. President is one of the best you'll ever work for and anyone who's worked with him long enough displays that.
cons: Some newer upper-level types bring a corporate vibe and different priorities that don't match with what attracted a lot of people to Road Scholar. Depts sometimes have conflicting goals at the micro level that communication could solve. Odd organizational snafus over the past few years that appear to be a constant work-in-progress and result of growing pains.

pros: I have been working for Road Scholar for a little over a month, and I can tell you this place cares about its employees. There are many people who have been working here for years, even decades. I personally know people who have been promoted from within, and there is mobility between the departments and even offices. I can see myself actually making a career here. I found the benefits to be amazing, and affordable. Also, you get to do a service training where you go on one of the programs and it's not counted toward vacation time! Also, you get discounts on programs as well. I am looking forward to using that. All in all, it's just been a wonderful environment and I am looking forward to growing with and supporting my department.
cons: I really can't think of anything at this time. Keep it up!

pros: I’ve had a very positive experience working at Road Scholar so far. There is great work-life balance and room for advancement if you work hard and show initiative. Benefits are good and there are some travel opportunities (more or less depending on which department you work for). A lot of great, knowledgeable people work here and are always willing to help when issues arise.
cons: We are constantly changing as an organization that sometimes it’s hard to keep up with new processes and procedures. There is no training program in place and there’s a lot of “learn as you go”, which can be seen as a positive or negative depending on your ability to pick things up quickly. I echo what everyone else says about salaries and that they could be higher considering the amount of work and location. But, I stay because I am happy working here and believe in the mission.

review_title: Benefits of Travel offset by Toxic Office Culture.
pros: Educational travel is part of your job. As individuals, the co-workers are fun, adventurous, and good people.
cons: I’ve never worked in such a toxic office. Good people, in the wrong positions makes for unhealthy conditions. There is an “gotcha” vibe—at times unprofessional,  at most times cliquish, environment. Siloed processes are created and then changed without clear oversight of how systems intersect. Seemed that the focus switched from mission-driven to finance driven. Performance outcomes are not correlated to mission outcomes.

review_title: There are other call centers out there where there is still respect for employees that go into work and do their best.
job_title: Participant Services Advisor in Lowell, MA
pros: Their medical, dental and vision is competitive as well as affordable, at least for a single person. I have been informed that it is competitive for a family plan as well.
cons: It takes a year before matching 401 k is applicable. There is excessive favoritism and some of the employees are still in high school mode where they feel the need to divulge their personal lives. The company does not foster innovation or change. The less you say and keep your head down or more drone or cronie like- the better for you.

review_title: Mixed experience but overall a disappointment
job_title: Call Center Advisor in Boston, MA
pros:
Shifts no later than 7pm
Colleagues are really nice
Employee discount off trips
More relaxed call center environment
cons:
Low pay
Little room for growth
Training was ok, but not great.
My manager was green so even they were nice they made rookie mistakes like constantly over promising 
Couldn't really speak out if there was an issue..considered confrontational and subordinate and supervisor would get scared you would go to HR

review_title: Internship is a scam and company use interns like a sweatshop. NO BENEFIT what so ever in this experience
pros:
1. Boss was reasonable
2. listen to music at work
3. flexible work schedule and lunch
4. surfing the internet
5. minimum supervision
cons:
1/ YOU LEARN NOTHING. The first day, they gave me an excel template and made me fill out all the informatin without explaining anything to me. 
2/ All their travel packages are overpriced and they don't seem to realize that GRAND CIRCLE TRAVEL is just better!
3/ unpaid
3/ No one except the person you report to will acknowledge you exist
4/ Computer and software programs are outdated
5/ Won't hire interns for full time position
6/ Experience was not a resume builder. No one ever asked me about this experience, complete waste of time.

review_title: Good Company that has some flaws
pros: There are good people that work at Road Scholar, and most of the employees care deeply about the programs that the company provides. There is a generous 403(b) employer match program.
cons: Zero room for growth or upward mobility in some departments. Non-competitive salaries for amount of work and effort that some employees put in.  A lack of accountability for employees that constantly make mistakes. The change management team doesn’t necessarily facilitate changes all that well. On occasion a terrible office band plays in the community space which can disrupt work.

pros:
1. Great benefits including retirement contributions.
2. Started some recent technological upgrades.
3. Excellent vision and mission.
4. Robust programs development and marketing.
5. Aggressively transforming the catalog economy into an e-tailing marketscape but is still managing to keep the catalog economy performing exceptionally.
6. Located right in the heart of downtown Boston.
7. Recently upgraded gym with free access.
8. Remote work flexibility.
9.  Recently hired some bright minds to revolutionalized the marketing department, a plus.
10. Takes needs of customers seriously by creating new ways to engage their customers and stay in touch.
11. Love the caregiver grant and other scholarships they award to customers. At least it gives a human face to the surpluses.
12. Employees get to travel on a program to get the first-hand experience of what it means to be a participant (customer) on their educational adventures.
13. I don't think there is junk food as some reviewers seem to suggest. Maybe that could be a problem at other offices, but rarely in Boston. Even if there is junk food you have the choice to resist it and walk down the street and get yourself a healthy lunch.
cons:
1. There is/are no clear guidance as to why or how promotions are awarded.  I had like to say that there is no transparency why x and z got promoted except for the fact that decisions are made behind closed doors and communicated.

2. You might likely be asked to report to someone who has no expertise and skills in the core function of your work. I personally think this was because of convenience. This was the key point that flipped my coin.

3. The overall marketing strategy is ironically focused on those who can buy their products (programs) but less so for those who can't afford it given that the organization seeks to promote and enhance lifelong learning and is a key player of the "University of the world" paradigm.

4. Performance review becomes an instrument where some Directors/Supervisors/Managers, etc make false review statements and expect you to accept. Make sure you respond to statements that you think was inaccurate on the Performance Review Form.

5. They may want you right where you are if you are an independent employee. That is, if only you do what you do. That is a dead end.

6. Salary is very moderate when compared with your position against state average and that of the city of work. Could that be the nonprofit thing?

review_title: Reality is very different when it comes to who they think they are.
pros: It was close to home, so the commute wasn't bad.
cons: Bullied, reprimanded, pushed, glared at...in all of the years I have been working, I was never treated like this. I was desperate for a job, having been laid-off (and single) and this job made my stomach do flips. One Monday morning, at about week 3 or 4, I just walked out, and I was elated when I did it (talk about getting glared at!), and I didn't have another job to go to at the time.  I expected some follow-up by them, but it was nothing but crickets. While I was in training, I heard that a lot of people quit early-on, and I was happy to join that statistic.

pros:
Road Scholar was such a wonderful company with an inspiring story and mission. Everyone who worked there (with the exception of a couple - no office is perfect!) was nice and supportive of their coworkers and fostered a really great team environment. Also, the CEO of this company is really an amazing guy. I respect him so much for going to great lengths to save RS during covid and being so communicative with his employees as well as the participants who pay for RS programs. He is going without pay until further notice to ensure others will be payed... so selfless! 

I worked in the Programs department which was in charge of developing educational trips/programs, scheduling everything for that trip, and then making sure everything was sent there that needed to be, etc. Our department was amazing and everyone in it really loved what they did and wanted to make sure the participants had the best experience possible. It was great to be part of a team that communicated and respected each other. 

Road Scholar also has a lot of community engagement opportunities and fun events. So it was great to have those times to meet people in other departments and take a mental break from work.
cons:
Just a couple cons. 
Pay- This comes with the territory of a non-profit, but generally speaking the benefits well make up for it. The health insurance was amazing and the 301b retirement plan was 100% matched by Road Scholar, which is unheard of. My main issue was that the pay scale didn't always make sense with the scale of the job. For instance, those on the phones made almost $18/hr, whereas the Programs Associates started at $16/hr... Don't get me wrong, I know being on the phones is mentally draining and difficult because you're dealing with sometimes frustrated customers all day, however, they are basically reading off a script all day long. The Programs Associates do a significant amount of work compared to that, and during the busiest seasons, barely have time to take a breath because their plates are so full. Quite honestly, it made the associates feel as they they were taken for granted and not respected.  Maybe have the start pay for the Programs Associates be the same as the phone jobs... would make a lot more sense and reduce animosity. 

The only other con I have is towards the contact center manager (only at the office I worked at in particular).  This manager could be incredibly condescending and rude. It was clear when she didn't like someone and she played favorites. I didn't even work for her, and this was something people knew. I honestly think that if upper management knew how she acted, they wouldn't have promoted her as much as they had.

pros: The people that work here are some of the best you'll meet, and the mission of the organization is interesting and special. Some of the benefits offered are really useful, especially for people living in the city.
cons:
It is very corporate in terms of messaging, and it the only reminder that it's a non-profit is the menial pay. I sometimes felt like they used their non-profit status primarily to justify the low salaries for everyone except senior staff and to save on postage. They will be better off if they become a commercial company rather than a non-profit. 

There was also an issue of transparency when I was there. Senior staff would ask for feedback and input but there was never really any follow through. There was also a huge range of talent among higher level mangers, some were excellent and others less so. 

There is also a "generational" divide that is pretty uncomfortable. Because the company is rapidly expanding, many new people are brought on, and those who have been working at Road Scholar for 10+ years seem to be wary of the growth and take those feelings out on the newer employees. It leads to tension at times and certain longtime employees projected feelings of superiority instead of seniority, which is a huge distinction. Most of the people are really pleasant, though.

review_title: Save yourself from this sinking ship!! There are much better companies out there.
pros: Summer and holiday outing. Nice new gym. Free coffee. I have to write more and that is all I can think of.
cons: Management is horrible- my entire department is going to be run down to the ground. Forced overtime hours. Extremely unprofessional management team that likes to blame the “little people” for anything that has gone wrong. Save yourself from being severely underpaid and work somewhere where you are actually valued as an employee. Do not work here. I wish I could give this company zero stars. There are so many other better companies out there.

job_title: Senior Marketing Writer in Boston, MA
pros: They really believe in their employees and give a lot of responsibility -- even if you're fresh out of college. You're encouraged to share your ideas and grow. I truly loved my department and trusted my team to the fullest extent, which can be hard to come by. I felt that my managers had my interests in mind.
cons: At a nonprofit, getting a raise or promotion can be difficult because there isn't as much money to go around. There also wasn't a ton of room to grow in my position.

pros:
Company culture is excellent, everyone is warm an welcoming. 
Great benefits--gym onsite at the Boston location, holiday time off and paid time off is sufficient. Schedule is pretty flexible, which is helpful for those with kids or that need to go to Doctors appointment
cons:
The company can be disorganized with processes. It makes is challenging to learn how to do tasks and meet expectations.
It's not clear how one can grow in the company-there is no road map currently, but HR is working on it.

pros:
Work life balance was good
Co-workers very friendly
Could listen to music at work
Easy going staff

company seems to do decently as a non-profit. the mission is respectable
cons:
Stuffing envelopes gets old pretty quickly
old database software
not much professional growth

there is a lot of work to be done, so it's understandable that an intern would be doing this kind of work

review_title: Treat people like children like it is a good thing?
pros: I had a job that was semi-flexible around my school schedule.  The people in Boston seem to be treated well.  Ask them to write more comments.
cons: Favoritism is for high school kids but these people are in their 40's and 50's treating the people who are working for them like they're in some clique and you cannot join.  Lots of talking behind backs lots of scheming.. Awful

pros: The organization provides opportunities to travel and participate with programs. The company provides decent benefits including medical, life, pet insurance. Because the clientele is well educated and desires an educational travel experience they expect perfection on a budget. When dealing with this particular type of customer, make sure you cross every "t" and dot every "i" because travel they expect a first rate experience on a beer budget.
cons: It is a not-for-profit organization. Pay is low.

pros: The location is wonderful.  The morale of the company is very good.  All the workers are friendly.  It is not chaotic like other competitors.
cons: This is a really hard. The benefits are good.  But you have to keep in mind that this is a non-profit organization.  Therefore, the benefits can appear to be less than what the competition offers.  They are making improvements!!

review_title: So happy to be gone! (Insert happy dance)
job_title: Call Center Representative in Lowell, MA
pros: There is always junk food in the office. I think they wanted us to get so big we couldn't leave our desk.  Basically, the junk food made up the depression everyone felt from being in the office. The other best part of working there was the sound of the door closing behind you on the way home.
cons: I was harassed for a long time and constantly told I was stupid, and worthless.  I was told to not use the bathroom because that is against the rules. Managers would stalk my desk and constantly watch me. I felt like I was in prison being punished for a crime I didn't commit. For a long time I took their harassment, thinking I was stupid, and worthless. I would leave in tears nearly everyday and lost the love for life I had before working their.   I would push back against the harassment and they labelled me as a problem employee because I spoke up for myself and the other employees for their unethical policies. Although, the customers liked me and the other staff would always come to me with questions because I was one of the only people that knew how to resolve problems.  The more drone like and quiet you are, the better for you. The constant harassment was extremely unhealthly and left me feeling terrible. I was depressed and could barely function from the harassment.  They play a sick game of making you feel bad about yourself to get you to perform better. Then, they feed you junk food to make you feel like you belong. If you value your self worth and intelligence I would highly suggest avoiding this workplace. Also, what someone else said about them getting rid of senior staff in the call center is correct and based on fact. They keep firing people around the first of the month for being off with their stats. I've been gone a little over two weeks and feel the weight off my shoulders.

review_title: Great co-workers and great mission; low end market value compensation
pros:
Road Scholar allows for a great work/life balance.
Hours are flexible.
Matching 401K plan.
Good company culture.
Small gym in the building.
You can occasionally travel with the company on a program for just the price of the transportation.
cons:
Compensation is on the low end of the market value. 
Woefully behind on technology across the board. They are working to improve this, but not at a fast pace.

pros: Good Work Environment, Nice Management, Good benefits, good work life balance, some room for growth
cons: It's really hard for people to get fired, so that means there are a good amount of incompetent workers. Salary is a bit under market and they use the "Not-for-profit" excuse. Feels like I've hit a glass ceiling for growth, there is nothing to be promoted into between current position and VP of finance.

pros: If you work there for over a year, you will be sent on a trip
cons: Lunch breaks were discouraged, vacation time requests were denied, pay is far below industry standards and raises are non existent.. It never feels good to be in that office. You're either buried in work or being criticized or blamed by someone higher up than you. Nothing is consistent, it seems like every item you work on needs to be handled in a completely different way.  Favoritism is a very big problem there. There is literally zero training. I learned my tasks by being told to do them with zero knowledge of how (using programs I've never seen before and were never previously mentioned), messing up and being criticized for it. It took me months to even learn what my actual work duties were because no one ever told me what my position was. Management is completely disconnected from staff. I was unable to use any of my vacation time, due to be denied.  This was because my manager was entirely unable to handle my day to day tasks for a couple days, even in low season.

pros:
Amazing company mission and culture. Very much appreciate my coworkers and staffs openness to collaborate. 
Company is working hard to implement ideas coming from any level of employee
cons: Difficult to work with other departments within the organization.

review_title: Great people to work with although lack of leadership
pros: The people at Road Scholar were great and loved the mission.
cons: There is lots of favoritism at the top, and a lack of clear vision and leadership.

review_title: My years at Road Scholar were filled with many different experiences. Managers are not hands on, employees are.
job_title: Participant Services Specialist in Lowell, MA
pros: Work at home benefit. Travel benefits. Pay is good. Each day was exciting.
cons: Advancement is difficult. Opinions are more valued than fact

review_title: A company culture and mission to believe in
pros: Working at Road Scholar was the most fulfilling job I've ever had. The company mission of lifelong learning attracts the most wonderful people.
cons: No clear road map for promotions or career advancement. Sometimes there can be a lack of communication between departments.

review_title: Believing in the mission is key to your happiness here
pros: Excellent colleagues, relaxed atmosphere, creativity encouraged, high quality programming and strong mission
cons: Salaries are low in comparison to the market. Sometimes too many cooks in the kitchen. Technology is outdated (but being improved!)

pros: Good for entry level positions and for parents, as they allow for a flexible schedule.
cons: The pay is not great.

job_title: Regional Program Manager in Boston, MA
pros: Laid back atmosphere-almost like family, flexible schedule, mission driven work, opportunities to travel, good salary/benefits for the travel industry
cons: Always challenges with work flows/processes, departments do not communicate around deadlines, no career pipeline, diversity/equity is not valued by management- do not be fooled by public statements

pros:
Interview was relatively easy. Mostly resume and a few behavioral. 
Management is great- offering you opportunity to learn and work on projects in areas of your strength
cons:
-low pay
-lack of training

pros:
- great culture with a great employees
- flexibility
- friendly & positive work environment
- good work/life balance
- long term employment
- employee centric
cons: - some growing pains as the company continues to mature

pros: Great training, strong feedback, good workplace culture with comradely feel.
cons: Really out-dated and unreliable technology. VERY corporate at times. For all the money they bring in, couldn't they upgrade?

pros: Enjoyed my time with them. Small Data Warehouse team with great vision and direction. Good technology stack and terrific environment with some of the brightest minds to collaborate with.
cons: Nothing I can think of.

pros: You sit in one place all day and talk to old people who are usually nice enough
cons: You sit in the same place all day and talk on the phone and listen to peoples complaints all day

review_title: Best organization to work for ever
pros:
Mission based
Balanced work life
Culture of collaboration
Senior Management
Long Term Vision
Free Coffee
Great Benefits 
Travel Perks
cons: Growing maybe a bit too fast

review_title: Treat the adults, like the adults that they are.
pros: You learn about the world
cons: You get treated like you are back in high school, except this time unless you're in management you're not a cool kid.

pros: Most genuinely kind and amazing coworkers and working environment.
cons: Somewhat of a smaller company so not much room for growth in terms of career advancement.

review_title: Good organization overall, great benefits and mission
pros: Motivating mission, great retirement plan and benefits including travel, good work environment most of the time
cons: Currently experiencing serious growing pains

job_title: Participant Services Representative in Lowell, MA
pros: They are fair, they allow you time off for family
cons: There are no cons, this is a fair company

pros:

Interesting projects
Excellent benefits

pros: Collaborative, innovative, great staff, great mission
